title: Intelligent car = safer roads

author: Ken Ducatel, DG Information Society and Media, European Commission

segmentation: Good morning ladies and gentlemen.
Thank you to organizers for inviting me here to give a short message on the behalf of my my boss Commissioner.
Reading responsible for Information Society and media.
And to express think the very short messages, my bosses total commitment to the area of innovation and development are in the area of transport.
As you probably know, she's only responsible for a tiny part of the overall transport portfolio, which he shares with her colleagues, Commissioner Potocnik, who was here yesterday.
Who's responsible also for lots of research spending in the area.
Mr Barrow, responsible for transport policy generally, and Mr Hogan responsible for industrial policy.

OK, so I'm not going to pretend to cover the entire ground and make some comments relevant to other Commissioners portfolios, but let me tell you that all of these Commissioners, as well as the college as a whole are very committed to the targets laid out in the White Paper.
Johnny preferred to, and I'm going to say a few things about.
About this and what we're doing, certainly from the portfolio of Mrs Redding now.
We are currently about 40,000 Rd deaths per year, 1.7 million people injured on Europe's roads every year, and although we've made quite a lot of progress already referred to.
30% reduction something like this was not in my commissioners view on track to achieve the 2010 target.
And if we really want to achieve this, then further policy measures will be necessary.

I'm part of the solution to achieving this goal is a very important goal, is to use all means available including innovations in the use of information and communication technologies in order to achieve lifesaving accident saving, distress saving and physical material damage saving gains in.
The safety of our roads systems.
This is one of the crucial.

Aspects of the Intelligent Car Initiative, which is one of the lead initiatives launched by Commissioner Reading at the start of her mandate, begin 2005 where we have tried to put together the different aspects of work we've been doing for a long time with different industrial partners and other stakeholders to create safer vehicles.
I don't know how this thing works, let's see.
Yeah, that's it OK?
Go back.
OK, so the Intelligent Car initiative which was launched in 2005 and which is a central part of the Commissioner strategy for Information Society in Europe, has we call up three pillars.
I've expanded the list here little bit here to give a little bit more detail.
On the one hand, our initiatives are two to build consensus among stakeholders.
Principally through the Safety Forum, which is a forum which has been very active and very important for us, but elsewhere as well.
This is very important part of making the whole.

Application development and application of new solutions of information technology for Rd safety and the work of the forum is now extending out beyond the safety of vehicles towards safety of infrastructures and towards cleaner vehicles and cleaner Rd transport more generally.
I'll set the second main pillar of the work that we have been doing is in the area of research, and here instead there are two aspects.
One is the research which is the traditional research funded under the framework instrument, the research framework, which is pretty competitive and which is relatively upstream.
Now this work has been going on under the research program for a long time and.

One of our concerns has been that although those very interesting research results around their translation into real application, and in this case saving of lives is slower than certainly we would like so one of the things we have been trying to do through the Intelligent Car initiative is to is to address this issue of the translation of research results into real life applications.

One of the reasons one of the ways we've been doing this, and we recently started this is an extension of the traditional role of the research instruments in downstream a little bit is to start to overcome some of the barriers.
Some of the technical and implementation barriers that we find in moving good research results into applications through large scale testing of different application areas.
So we've been doing.
Field trials for field operational trials and I'll refer to some of these things a little bit later.
And then the third area is policy measures.
And here is the sense.

Well, well, my my Commissioner has less of the competence is to lead, but nevertheless we have been doing work and under her portfolio and in collaboration with other Commissioners on the development of the equal system.
On trying to create a market more coherent spectrum policy and working on issues relating to the privacy aspects concerning the integration of.
A lot of driver details of Rd traffic information and making sure that this information is protected under the privacy laws which are existing in Europe.

Try again.
So save us from death by PowerPoint.

Off, which are the the main elements which we have to take into account when we're looking at Rd safety and what we've seen is is that most of the efforts of Commissioner readings portfolio have been in the area of vehicle work.
Equal is situated somewhere between the vehicle and the infrastructural developments and then we have some of the new developments.
The Electronic Stability Control Systems, which is somewhere between vehicle and driver I would say.
Enhance breaking assistant emergency breaking assistance and adaptive cruise control are areas which are somewhere between vehicle and drivers.
This is an area which we have chosen.

This is this concentration on the vehicle we have chosen as the principle priority for commissioners readings initiatives because we believe that is the area where we can work very closely with industrial stakeholders in order to make progress.
And that's what my Commission wanted to see.
She's a very practical person.
She wants to make rapid progress.
This is the area where we can do these things.
Let's take a couple of examples and of where we are an implementation issues and I want to talk briefly about equal and electronic stability control.
I'm.
Equal when it's fully rolled out according to our impact assessments, can could save about 2 1/2 thousand lives.
That would get us like another five to six, 7% down towards our target.
We are aiming at a rollout by 2010.
And there I think are good signs that we are on track to get towards a full implementation in Europe by 2010.

We have the endorsement now of 13 Member States and two Norman states in Europe, Norway and Switzerland, and we have Hungary, Luxembourg and Slovakia waiting in the wings to sign the Memorandum of understanding and this is moved ahead substantially from situation when Commissioner Reading took charge in 2005.
I find more encouraging is actually even those countries which have not signed up officially to the Memorandum of understanding for various internal issues.
These countries are still working on the development and implementation of equal or equal type systems.

In particular, for instance to my country, my home country, the UK, where we see that even though it hasn't signed up the memory understanding understanding in practice work is going on in order to upgrade the work in the in the course enters the Circle Piece apps in order to make sure these services are available.
So we believe on this area we are going to make progress, but this is an area where we have not just to work on the vehicle.
It's not just a question of getting the manufacturers to install these systems or for the suppliers to create retrofit fit systems which can be put into your car.
It's a question of getting the infrastructure upgrade.
In this case the emergency call systems and this is the really tough work.
This is the work which requires more time because it requires public decision-making and public.
Budget allocation and equipment by.
By senior policymakers to go in this direction.
This is where a lot of our political work has been addressed and where the challenge is still very strong.
We believe we can get there, and we will continue to work on on this in order to achieve our target.
If we look at the.
Electro petranek stability control item.
Here the people talk about this as though it may be the next biggest saver of lives after the safety belt could be saving, say, 4000 lives a year.
The aim here is to get 100% of all new vehicles entering the market, putting on being put on the market by 2012.
Actually equipped with this as a standard feature.
Um?
In this case, we are going down the route of a voluntary.

Action through the Choose ESC campaign, which I think is presented here, which we launched last year in May in Rome, and we see some progress and of the level of the new cars which are equipped with this is me on the markets moving from 43 up to 47% were still quite a long way behind the United States, which is I understand is about 63%.

On this high variations from one country to another, from one model to another, and again, political work is going on here, we see a very strong collaboration between Mr Heikkinen, Mrs. Reading in order to achieve this, and in both these instances if our political efforts to make sure that the work of the industry and the work of other stakeholders is not being translated into appropriate conditions in the markets.
In Europe we are prepared to regulate in order to make these things go ahead.

So in the latest communication on intelligent car concerning equal, we have put on the table the idea that we are willing to make a directive on equal in order to make this become a reality in Europe.
In order to save lives, we have very strong support of the Parliament in this and we believe that should be have to go in this direction that we will be able to achieve this in a very short time.

On the ESC on Electronic stability control we are certainly considering standardizing this through a legal instrument in Europe and we OK. We think we can get there a lot way along way with the market, but in order to give legal certainty for players on the market, maybe there.
Again we will be seeing Commission action now I'd like to leave for the question and answers concerns about issues relating to where we're going with new technologies.
We have a lot to say about what we're doing in terms of new developments of research going forward and what might be some of the barriers to the take up of these these technologies.
Lifesaving technologies.
I'd rather like to hand over to my colleagues for the next part of the discussion.
Thank you.
